comment._content: Generally speaking, this wig would be a symbol of his Judicial office. In British Courts, generally, wigs are also worn by Barristers-At-Law, who appear representing the prosecution or the defence in court. Barristers' wigs do not have the long sides depicted here. Nor do Barristers wear the type of robe depicted here. Isaacs was appointed Lord Chief Justice, 2nd most senior law officer ( roughly the equivalent of the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the USA) in 1913. Although I am not expert in legal regalia, I believe the chain he is wearing in this photograph is part of the regalia associated with the Office of Lord Chief Justice of England and Wales (e.g. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rayner_Goddard,_Baron_Goddard )

comment.author: 32573662@N00
comment._content: That particular collar of office or livery collar is known as a Collar of Esses, for the S-shapes in the design. According to Christie's, "These collars of office became the personal property of each Lord Chief Justice and were subsequently sold, upon the office-holder's retirement, to the incoming occupier of the post." Christie's also says that when the office of Lord Chief Justice of England was created in 1880 from the merging of two other offices, a new chain of office was made; presumably that 1880 chain is the one we see here, as well as on the current Lord Chief Justice in this photo. Not sure if the wig & coat are also passed down, but presumably Isaacs' coat was also scarlet in color.
